statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

article.description: Brian Grant, who needed five stitches to close a gashed chin in the fourth quarter, hit two jumpers in the final 1:22 of overtime Monday night to lead the Miami Heat to their fifth straight win, 95-93 over Cleveland.
article.headline: Grant receives stitches, keeps clicking
article.linkText: Tough chin: Grant returns in OT to lift Heat over Cavs
article.story:
CLEVELAND (AP) -- Brian Grant took one on the chin, and then knocked the Cleveland Cavaliers out with a 1-2 punch. Grant, who needed five stitches to close a gashed chin in the fourth quarter, hit two jumpers in the final 1:22 of overtime Monday night to lead the Miami Heat to their fifth straight win, 95-93 over Cleveland. The Cavaliers have lost 10 in a row. Grant refused to come to Cleveland in a sign-and-trade deal as a free agent before last season, and he stuck it to the Cavs again by making two nearly identical 16-foot jumpers. "I was the first option on both those shots," said Grant, whose chin was split open by teammate Alonzo Mourning's elbow. "I know I can hit the shot. Both times I had a good look." Grant spent the final seven minutes of regulation in the locker room getting stitched up and came back just in time to bail out his teammates, who allowed the Cavs to overcome an eight-point deficit in the final 1:34 of regulation. "We were very lucky to win," Miami coach Pat Riley said. "We had the game in hand. We let them back in it. We got the win, that's all it's about. But I don't think we should have gone to overtime to do it." The Cavs had a chance to win in OT, but Jumaine Jones missed a 3-pointer just before time expired. Eddie Jones scored 27 points, Mourning had 15 before fouling out and rookie Mike James had a season-high 12 as the Heat continued their slow turnaround after a dreadful start. Miami, which began the year 2-14, has won eight of 11 and avoided being swept in the four-game season series by Cleveland. Three of the four games went to overtime. "We needed this win," Grant said. "We're playing well and wanted it to continue." Wesley Person had 19 points and Andre Miller 17 and 12 assists for the Cavs, who trailed 85-77 before rallying to tie it at 87-all on two free throws by Zydrunas Ilgauskas with 8.8 seconds left. Eddie Jones missed a jumper just before the regulation horn and then hit a running one-hander from the baseline to tie it at 91 with 2:18 left in OT. After Miller missed a 3-pointer, LaPhonso Ellis grabbed a big offensive rebound and found Grant, who drilled his shot from just to the left of the foul line. After Ilgauskas missed, Grant came through again, working a pick-and-roll with Rod Strickland and dropping in another jumper with 45 seconds to play to put the Heat up 95-91. "Man, I feel great for him," Mourning said of Grant. "He went out and made big plays for us. I'm the one who took him out of the game. I turned around and popped him right in the chin." Ricky Davis scored for Cleveland, and the Cavs got a final chance only to have Jones hit the back of the rim with his 3. "I want to be in those situations with the game on the line," Jones said. "I stepped up and took it, unfortunately it didn't go in." Jumaine Jones had 14 points and Ilgauskas 13 for the Cavs, who just returned from an 0-6 road trip and remained winless since Jan. 2. Cleveland was without leading scorer Lamond Murray, who had surgery on Monday to reset his broken nose. Murray was injured during a loss at Los Angeles on Saturday night and will miss the next two weeks. The Cavs also lost 10 straight from Jan. 27-Feb. 17 last season. With Jones making four of his five 3-pointers, Miami, which came in as the league's lowest-scoring team, shot 61 percent from floor in the first half and led 52-41 at halftime. Jones, who had 19 first-half points, was on target from the outset. Spotting up on the arc, he made three 3-pointers in a three-minute span and scored 14 points in the first period as the Heat opened a 30-21 lead after one.

Game notes
The Cavs hadn't played three OT games against the same team in one season since 1974-75 vs. Atlanta. ... Cavs coach John Lucas said F Tyrone Hill, who hasn't played this season because of a bad back, is improving and could be activated in the next 10-12 days. ... To replace Murray, the Cavs activated guard Trajan Langdon. ... Eddie Jones has scored in double-digits in a quarter 17 times this season. ... Ilgauskas and Davis both left the morning shootaround with flu-like symptoms and were doubtful until tipoff.
